Package RautSoft.math.calculus

The package contains two main classes, Integration and Differentiation, each containing several static methods that can perform perform integration and differentiation of a function of one or more variables.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
Differentiation Calculates the gradient and the Hessian of a function of many variables
Integration The package contains two main classes, Integration and Differentiation, each containing several static methods that can perform integration and differentiation of a function of one or more variables.
 

Package RautSoft.math.calculus Description

The package contains two main classes, Integration and Differentiation, each containing several static methods that can perform perform integration and differentiation of a function of one or more variables. The functions are passed as

Integration Methods

  • Gaussian Quadrature see Integration.qgaus(FunctionOfOneVariable func, double a, double b)
  • Romberg's method see Integration.qromb(FunctionOfOneVariable func, double a, double b)
  • Simpson's Rule see Integration.qsimp(FunctionOfOneVariable func, double a, double b)
  • Trapezoid's Rule, see Integration.trapzd(FunctionOfOneVariable func, double a, double b, int n)
The default values of JMAX=20 and EPS=1.0e-10 could be changed before calling a method. The computations algorithms are adopted from Numerical Recipe book, and various other books and published articles.

Usage Example 

 
import RautSoft.Interfaces.FunctionOfOneVariable;
import static RautSoft.math.calculus.Integration.*;
import RautSoft.math.calculus.*;

public class IntegrationEx {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        
        FunctionOfOneVariable f = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
            public double value(double x) {
                return (1/(Math.sqrt(2*Math.PI))*Math.exp(-(x*x)/2));
            }
        };
                double a = -1.96, b = 1.96;
        double result = qtrap(f, a, b, 1);
        System.out.println("Using Trapezoid rule qtrap() with JMAX=20 is " +result);
        
        result = qsimp(f, a, b);
        System.out.println("Using Simpson's rule qsimp() is " +result);
        
        result = qromb(f, a, b);
        System.out.println("Using Romberg's rule qromb() is " +result);
        
        result = qgaus(f, a, b);
        System.out.println("Using Gaussian quadrature qgaus() is " +result);
        Integration in =new Integration(); //create this object if you want
        //to change the paramters
        in.EPS=1.e-15;
        in.JMAX=20;
        result = qromb(f, a, b);
        System.out.println("Using Trapezoid rule qromb() with JMAX=10 and EPS=1.0e-15 is " +result);
        
    }
}

Output of the above program

Using Trapezoid rule qtrap() with JMAX=20 is 0.475002104855909
Using Simpson's rule qsimp() is 0.4750021048533908
Using Romberg's rule qromb() is 0.4750021048516825
Using Gaussian quadrature qgaus() is 0.4750021047637146
Using Trapezoid rule qromb() with JMAX=10 and EPS=1.0e-15 is 0.4750021048517797

Related Documentations

  • Example1

Differentiation Methods

The calss Differentiation has several methods to return the grad and Hessian of a function of one or more variables. Here are some of the important ones, all these methods are overloaded to return the derivatives both as a function of x, at which derivative is taken, or as a double value for the derivative at a particular point x.
  • grad(): computes the gradient vector of a function (returns as a vector valued function of x, or a 1-D double array for a given x)
  • HessianSingleElement(): Hessian  of a single element i, j ((returns as a function of x, or a double for a given x)
  • diffRiddersMethod() : returns a double as the derivative of a function of one variable at a given x, using Ridders' method (for computational details on this method see Numerical Recipe).

Example of Use 

  import RautSoft.util.nrutil.*;
import static RautSoft.util.nrutil.*;
import static RautSoft.math.calculus.Differentiation.*;
import RautSoft.math.calculus.*;
import RautSoft.Interfaces.*;

public class DifferentiationEX {
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        FunctionOfOneVariable f = new FunctionOfOneVariable(){
            public double value(double x){
                return x*x;
            }
        };
        pDouble error = new pDouble(-999);
        double df = diffRiddersMethod(f,3,.01,error);
        System.out.println("The derivative of f(x) = x^2 at x = 3: is " + df );
        System.out.println("The estimated error = " + error.value);
        
        FunctionOfManyVariables   myf   = new FunctionOfManyVariables(){
            public double value(double[] x){
                return (x[0]*x[0] + 2*x[1]*x[1] );
            }
        };
        Differentiation ex = new Differentiation();
        double[] x0 ={2, 3};
        FunctionOfManyVariables gradf;
        double d = grad(1, myf,0.000001).value(x0);
        System.out.println("Grad at x = " + d );
        //The overloaded grad returns double
        d = grad(1, myf,x0);
        System.out.println("Grad at x = " + d );
        double h = HessianSingleElement(1,1,myf,.01).value(x0);
        System.out.println("Hessian at x = " + h );
        //the overloaded gradf function returns a double
        h = HessianSingleElement(1,1,myf,x0);
        System.out.println("Hessian at x = " + h );
    }
    
}

Output of the above program

    
The derivative of f(x) = x^2 at x = 3: is 6.000000000000088
The estimated error = 2.1582735598713043E-13
Grad at x = 12.000000001677336
Grad at x = 12.000000000000455
Hessian at x = 3.9999999999906777
Hessian at x = 4.000000000164761
